Award.AwardTitle: PI Meeting for Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports development of the program for a 2.5- to 3-day workshop to bring together PIs from across the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program. The PI is formulating a steering committee that is in turn identifying topics and establishing a workshop agenda, including speakers and panelists. Specific objectives of the PI meeting include:

- to stimulate coordination and collaboration amongst SaTC PIs working on different projects;
- to foster new collaborations between SaTC researchers and researchers in other disciplines;
- to share experiences and learn from others' experiences in transitioning research into practice; and
- to develop ideas and share methods for improving education, recruitment, and career development in cybersecurity.

Building a strong community among SaTC researchers helps identify new research topics, avoid duplication of existing research, and improve educational opportunities for graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the organization of the National Science Foundation Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Principal Investigators' Meeting, held in Arlington, VA, 5-7 January 2015.

The meeting brought together a broad group of researchers working on security and privacy including over 380 academic researchers, as well as participants from funding agencies and industry.

Nearly all of the materials from the meeting (including videos of the sessions) are available on a public website, https://www.usenix.org/conference/satcpi15. Additional supporting materials are available at http://www.rematchr.org/, and the source code used for supporting the meeting and arranging rapid-fire cross collaboration meetings is available under an open source license.

To foster new collaborations and interactions among people from different backgrounds and research areas, the meeting included a rapid-fire cross-collaborations session where participants were matched in groups of 2-4 researchers for a short discussion. To support this, the PIs developed software for analyzing the text in public NSF abstracts and arranging individual and small group meetings according to various criteria.

The meeting include 18 breakout groups, organized by the PI with help from the organizing committee and volunteer leaders.  Participants were assigned to a breakout group based on matching participants to their interests as well as ensuring an intellectually diverse group with a variety of backgrounds in each breakout session.
